citing_paper_authors: Dan, Garrette | Jason, Mielens | Jason, Baldridge
raw_text: To see how differences in annotator speed and quality impact our task, we obtained ENG data from an experienced annotator and a novice one. Ngai and Yarowsky (2000) investigated the effectiveness of rule-writing versus annotation (using active learning) for chunking, and found the latter to be far more effective
clean_text: Ngai and Yarowsky (2000) investigated the effectiveness of rule-writing versus annotation (using active learning) for chunking, and found the latter to be far more effective.

raw_text: Another relatively early work in our field along these lines was the work of Ngai and Yarowsky (2000), which measured actual times of annotation to compare the efficacy of rule writing versus annotation with AL for the task of BaseNP chunking
clean_text: Another relatively early work in our field along these lines was the work of Ngai and Yarowsky (2000), which measured actual times of annotation to compare the efficacy of rule writing versus annotation with AL for the task of BaseNP chunking.

raw_text: In contrast to the model presented byNgai and Yarowsky (2000), which predicts monetary cost given time spent, this model estimates time spent from characteristics of a sentence
clean_text: In contrast to the model presented by Ngai and Yarowsky (2000), which predicts monetary cost given time spent, this model estimates time spent from characteristics of a sentence.

raw_text: Ngai and Yarowsky (2000) used an ensemble based on bagging and partitioning for active learning for base NP chunking
clean_text: Ngai and Yarowsky (2000) used an ensemble based on bagging and partitioning for active learning for base NP chunking.

raw_text: In our annotation experiments, we measure the exact time taken to annotate each example by each annotator and use this as the cost metric, inspired by Ngai and Yarowsky (2000)
clean_text: In our annotation experiments, we measure the exact time taken to annotate each example by each annotator and use this as the cost metric, inspired by Ngai and Yarowsky (2000).

citing_paper_authors: Roi, Reichart | Katrin, Tomanek | Udo, Hahn | Ari, Rappoport
raw_text: AL has been successfully applied already for a wide range of NLP tasks, including POS tagging (Engelson and Dagan, 1996), chunking (Ngai and Yarowsky, 2000), statistical parsing (Hwa, 2004), and named entity recognition (Tomanek et al, 2007) .However, AL is designed in such a way that it selects examples for manual annotation with respect to a single learning algorithm or classifier
clean_text: AL has been successfully applied already for a wide range of NLP tasks, including POS tagging (Engelson and Dagan, 1996), chunking (Ngai and Yarowsky, 2000), statistical parsing (Hwa, 2004), and named entity recognition (Tomanek et al, 2007).

citing_paper_authors: Alexis, Palmer | Taesun, Moon | Jason, Baldridge
raw_text: These measures are convenient for performing active learning simulations, but awareness has grown that they are not truly rep re sentative measures of the actual cost of annotation (Haertel et al, 2008a; Settles et al, 2008), with Ngai and Yarowsky (2000) being an early exception to the unit-cost approach
clean_text: These measures are convenient for performing active learning simulations, but awareness has grown that they are not truly representative measures of the actual cost of annotation (Haertel et al, 2008a; Settles et al, 2008), with Ngai and Yarowsky (2000) being an early exception to the unit-cost approach.

citing_paper_authors: Katrin, Tomanek | Joachim, Wermter | Udo, Hahn
raw_text: In their study on AL for base noun phrase chunking, Ngai and Yarowsky (2000) compare the costs of rule-writing with (AL-driven) annotation to compile a base noun phrase chunker
